required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Accupressure of P6 to Reduce Nausea During Cesarean Section
clinical_study.official_title: The Use of P6 Acupressure for the Reduction of Intraoperative and Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting in Women Undergoing Cesarean Delivery: a Randomized Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate if the addition of P6 pressure point stimulation as opposed to sham-point stimulation will decrease intraoperative and postoperative nausea and vomiting (IONV and PONV) for patients undergoing non-emergent cesarean delivery. We hypothesize that the addition of stimulation of the P6 pressure point to our institutional current standard of care (phenylephrine infusion, intravenous fluid bolus, and as needed intraoperative ondansetron) will decrease the occurrence of intraoperative emesis.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Two group, sham vs actual location of pressure point.
study_design_info.masking_description: Participant will not know whether the pressure point is correct or sham location.

primary_outcome.measure: Presence of emesis during scheduled cesarean delivery
primary_outcome.description: Presence of emesis during the scheduled cesarean delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Presence of nausea during scheduled cesarean delivery
secondary_outcome.description: The presence of nausea during the scheduled cesarean delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: presence of nausea after scheduled cesarean delivery
secondary_outcome.description: The presence of nausea after scheduled cesarean delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal satisfaction of the IONV/PONV management using a VAS
secondary_outcome.description: Maternal satisfaction with IONV/PONV medical management using a sliding VAS (visual analog scale) of 0 representing poor satisfaction and 10 representing greatest level of satisfaction. The maternal satisfaction with intraoperative and postoperative nausea and vomiting management.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of antiemetic rescue medications given during the intraoperative period
secondary_outcome.description: Total number of additional antiemetic rescue medications given during the intraoperative period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of additional antiemetic rescue medications given postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: Total number of number of additional antiemetic rescue medications given during the post operative period.

arm_group.description: The pressure point will be stimulated by the presence of the magnet when positioned properly on the P6 acupressure point. Additional pressure may be applied as desired by the study subject but is not necessary for P6 stimulation.
The sham pressure point (distal to the P6 acupressure point).

intervention.description: Magnet applied at P6 and attached with adhesive tape. The P6 pressure point is 2 inches proximal to the flexor retinaculum, between the flexor carpi radialis and palmaras longus.

intervention.intervention_name: Magnet applied to arm not at P6 pressure point.
intervention.description: Magnet applied to arm not at P6 pressure point and affixed with adhesive tape.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- â‰¥18 years of age
- English-speaking
- Pregnant patients presenting for scheduled cesarean delivery of a full-term fetus (>37 weeks' gestation)
- Patients scheduled as ERAC
- Parturients undergoing spinal anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients requiring emergent delivery,
- Fetal demise
- Patients with adhesive allergy/sensitivity
- Patients with allergy/sensitivity to nickel,
- Patients with inability to consent,
- Patients with known abnormal placentation
- Patients with pacemakers/defibrillators
- Patients with positive COVID-19 tests
